. I found other problem, commenting at line start not working nice with gofmt:
``` go
package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
    fmt.Println("Hello, 世界")
}
```
now comment line with Println:
``` go
package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
//  fmt.Println("Hello, 世界")
}
```
and after saving file (with gofmt on):
``` go
package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
    //  fmt.Println("Hello, 世界")
}
```
Same problem with bigger indentation levels. Inserting // at text start should fix that problem.

. https://github.com/bradfitz/goimports

This tool updates your Go imports, adding missing ones and removing
unreferenced onces.
It's a fork of gofmt, and will also fmt your code, so it can be used
as a replacement for your gofmt-on-save hook in your editor.

On golang-nuts: https://groups.google.com/d/msg/golang-nuts/ahPVZ9htw7s/Nhvi50jjGd4J

It's gofmt + it fixes your includes, adding missing ones and removing unreferenced ones.
You can make it your editor's on-save hook, and then not worry about imports. 

Best regards,
Dobrosław Żybort

Ubuntu 16.04 Qt5
Install Qt5
$ sudo apt-get update

$ ./build_linux_qt5.sh

$ cd ~/liteide/build/liteide/bin
$ ./liteide

$ ./deploy_linux_x64_qt5.sh
32 bit

. Same Problem here with Kubuntu 16.04, for example: 
Ctrl+R (Build and Run) does NOT work (neither does Ctrl+F7), 
Ctrl+B (Build) for example is one of the few that does work.
Ctrl+Alt+R (Run) does not work (but Ctrl+F5 does work)
There are many more that don't work but there does not seem to be a common pattern to it.
[Edit]
When I press Ctrl+R this appears on stdout/stderr:
QAction::eventFilter: Ambiguous shortcut overload: Strg+R
And in fact when I go to KDE shortcut settings in the section application shortcuts there is Ctrl+R bound to "Replace". Surely there must be a way to redefine these by the application in a way that does not lead to a conflict, there are 80 (!) different shortcuts listed on this page and some of them are really simple ones like "page up" or "F3", 
I cannot believe that KDE will block all these shortcuts for all applications, these are clearly not global shortcuts (like Alt-Tab), these are shortcuts that only affect behavior inside the application, I'm not even shure how it is KDE's business caring about any of these shortcuts at all. Maybe some of them are default shortcuts for Qt widgets like Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V for copy/paste but there must be a documented way to override these reliably, I cannot imagine this is not possible.

On Sat, Mar 15, 2014 at 2:45 PM, Marc Noirot notifications@github.comwrote:

"Tabs as Spaces" makes no sense, since a space is just this, a single
space between characters, so the TAB character should never be inserted
when pressing the SPACE key, right ?
Concerning go format, it is written in the official language
recommendations at http://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#formattingthat:
We use tabs for indentation and gofmt emits them by default. Use spaces
only if you must.
However, gofmt has two options:
-tabs=true: indent with tabs
  -tabwidth=8: tab width
So if calling gofmt -tabs=false -tabwidth=4, the desired result should be
achieved.
So what remains is for LiteIDE to actually adjust gofmt's options
according to its own settings.
(Unless it is calling go fmt which does not allow spaces as tabs).

fawick:
I get the same error with LiteIDE X19 on Windows 7. The second tab appears, when I double click on a build error in the Build Output widget. The second tab omits the Windows drive letter (e.g. 'C:').
For example:
1) I have a tab for file "c:/go/test.go" (verified by hovering mouse over tab name)
2) I write a syntax error in text.go and click on build
3) Build Output might report the error like
c:\go\test.go:123: syntax error: unexpected name, expecting semicolon or newline or }
4) I double click the error message
5) A new tab is opened for "/go/test.go" (again, checked by hovering mouse over tab name)
6) When I correct the error in the second tab and save it, I might receive a message that the file in the first tab has changed and whether I want to reload it from disk.
So, the problem seems to be that LiteIDE does not detect that "c:/go/test.go" and "/go/test.go" are the same file. 
. After browsing the source code I think the problem is in litebuild.cpp in the method:
void LiteBuild::dbclickBuildOutput(const QTextCursor &cur)
I guess the RegExp  m_outputRegex should be constructed differently on Windows system to respect the drive letter and the colon that goes with it.
Currently, I cannot compile LiteIDE, so I cannot write and test a bugfix.
EDIT: Another Idea might be to check what happens in 
IEditor *EditorManager::findEditor(const QString &fileName, bool canonical)
and edit 
bool FileUtil::compareFile(const QString &fileName1, const QString &fileName2, bool canonical)
so that on Windows systems the canonical paths of "c:\go\test.go" and "\go\test.go" can be considered identical.
. The problem is not really caused by liteide, as the output of go build is the lower-case version from the real path names in the file system, so the changed behaviour is to my Go installation being updated to go 1.2 in the mean time where it has been 1.1.2 before when I commented on #72

warpfork:
+1, I need this too, badly.  No sane project shares a single GOPATH with the rest of the system; it's a guaranteed way to break builds on a daily basis when unrelated projects are allowed to clobber each other's library sources.
. I'm hacked this by wrapping liteide in a shell script that does HOME=/projects/$projectName liteide and templates out the gopath with sed hacks.  I feel terrible about this, but it works.  On the off chance it's useful to anyone else out there, here's a snippet:
``` bash
fakeHome="$litespace/$projConf"
mkdir -p "$fakeHome/.config/liteide/"
iniFile="$fakeHome/.config/liteide/liteide.ini"
if the file doesn't exist yet, try to start with the one in the homedir.
if it does, we'll just rewrite it; don't want to through away open files and such state.
[ -f "$iniFile" ] || cp "$HOME/.config/liteide/liteide.ini" "$iniFile" || touch "$iniFile"
this rewrite is a hair tricky since the line of interest may not exist yet
first we get rid of the line of interest if it does
then we append the section header if it doesn't exist yet
then we put the desired value right after the section header
sed -i '/^gopath=/d' "$iniFile"
grep '^[liteide]$' "$iniFile" >/dev/null || echo -e "\n[liteide]" >> "$iniFile"
sed -i 's/^[liteide]$/[liteide]\n'"gopath=${projectDir//\//\/}\/${gopath//\//\/}/" "$iniFile"
yes, yes I did just template inputs to sed with bash.  WHAT COULD GO RONG
HOME="$fakeHome" liteide
```
(There's some variables you'd need to set for the above to work; https://gist.github.com/heavenlyhash/27db671839a21f5e936c has the rest of my project workspace autodetection; YMMV on that part.)
.

Since Vista console applications don't receive a close signal before being terminated (meaning the signals don't arrive for it to perform a correct shut down).  As such when you stop the application running it dies in a bad manner.  However it does still receive this message above as a shut down signal allowing the application to do the correct process.  So sending this first would be best (then killing the application if it does not have any results).
Otherwise could you add support for ctrl + c in the output console to be sent through to the application allowing manual support.

noirotm:
"Tabs as Spaces" makes no sense, since a space is just this, a single space between characters, so the TAB character should never be inserted when pressing the SPACE key, right ?
Concerning go format, it is written in the official language recommendations at http://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#formatting that:

We use tabs for indentation and gofmt emits them by default. Use spaces only if you must.

However, gofmt has two options:
-tabs=true: indent with tabs
  -tabwidth=8: tab width
So if calling gofmt -tabs=false -tabwidth=4, the desired result should be achieved.
So what remains is for LiteIDE to actually adjust gofmt's options according to its own settings.
(Unless it is calling go fmt which does not allow spaces as tabs).
. I don't see the point of not respecting the canonical style anyways.
Go is a simple language which is easily readable as long as the official style, which is clever enough, is used.

. The following script updates the file ticker.go with the current date-time every five seconds :
```
file loop.sh :
!/bin/bash
echo "date: xxx" > ticker.go
echo "As long as this script is running, the file ticker.go will be modified every 5 seconds."
echo "looping ..."
echo "press ^C to interrupt"
while true; do
  dt=date "+%F %T"
  sed -i "s/^date: .*$/date: $dt/" ticker.go
  sleep 5
done
```
Steps :
- run this script, and leave it running
- run liteide, and open the file "ticker.go"

Cergoo:
local packages no are bad, just this dude does not know how to build them
- you must set a main file to build (go build mypkg.go)
- you must generally stick to the principle: "one package main (includeed main function) is a single executable file is a single package file." 
There is a difference between a package of main and packages with other names.
For other (not main) packets, there is no problem lies in different files. Moreover, it kind of implicit in the semantics of the team go build, which you specify the directory in which is collected in the package...
For main packages situation is different. For example you have in the project means several executable files. That is at the root of the project will be based on several files in the package main, and in each of its func main().
Now imagine that you have there another file with the package main, but does not have its func main(). And? That will make the compiler when you run the General Assembly of the project 'go build'?

. OK, I got (possibly overly) decisive. I have created the LiteIDE organization and forked this repository to it. People willing to be active in moving the fork forward let me know and I will add you to the organization.
. @VincenzoLaSpesa invite sent.
. I have forked this project to https://github.com/LiteIDE/liteide. Currently I am trying to work out how to replace the shell script based build system with a SCons or CMake based one. So there appears to be no activity on that repository either, but there is work going on. If anyone wants to join in developing LiteIDE, please feel free to send in pull requests to that repository. If this repository becomes active again then we will see how to merge activity to avoid any conflict or dilution of effort.
. @visualfc I propose that you take over leadership of the project in the LiteIDE organization and the focus of development moves there. I will in a moment invite you to the ownership group of the LiteIDE project. It should then not be difficult to move things to there from here. I think the protocol might be that we delete the current LiteIDE repository in the LiteIDE organization, you change ownership of this repository to LiteIDE and then take a new personal fork.
The point at issue here is that the project is too important to a number of people in the Go community for it to be a "one man project" and therefore subject to the "man under a bus" scenario. By moving the project to an organization there can be more than one person available to be at the helm. There is clearly a community of people here willing to be involved in development, so let's harness that so as to really make LiteIDE the premier Go development environment. Doing this also acts as marketing to the wider community that this is not just one persons pet project, it is a project that has become strategically important to many, many people, and is being managed in an appropriate way.
. @pierrre There is already a LiteIDE organization, I created it when there was great anxiety that @visualfc had got into a situation of no return. I made it clear then that this was a defensive fork, not an aggressive one, and that there was no intention to take the project from @visualfc. I think though this is now a great opportunity to turn LiteIDE into a mainstream project, that it would be good all round if @visualfc agreed to moving the project mainline from his personal repository to the LiteIDE organization so that a team of people can coalesce around him and support him as leader of the organization and the project.
. @visualfc You asked that no fork be made, but have not responded re the proposal that you lead the LiteIDE organization with others in the committer team. Currently the project just seems to have restarted as a one-person pet project as previous. I suggest this project is too important to a large number of people in the Go community to be a one-person pet project.
. @gdm85 The thread may be endless, but as yet, it has not reached uselessness. When @visualfc was away, I forked the project into an organization owned repository not to fragment or fork in the "I have a different idea about this", but to create a stable mainline that people could work on and keep moving. A successful project creates a community and that community deserves the ability to have continuity. A mainline with many guardians is a show of maturity of a large project with a active community; it is a badge of honour for a project, and a message to the wider world that the project is not going away.
@visualfc asked explicitly that I not fork the project. No supporting argument was made. I asked if @visualfc would take control of the organization and mainline repository I had created but there has been no answer to this as yet. We have therefore returned to this being a one person project with no core group of developers providing continuity. I find this very sad for such a useful project as this. It is a retrograde step back to hobby project status. This severely undermines confidence that organizations using Go can have in this project. But if this is what @visualfc wants then fine. It would just be good to have direct messages not speculation by others. 
. @gdm85 You are missing the main point of what I did, and what has happened subsequently. I think there is no point in "bikeshedding" here, I do not disagree with much of what you say about projects and communities in general, but this thread is only about this one project and how to make it into the "product" it deserves to be.
. @gdm85  What flames, I was just assuming we were having a robust debate. 
. @NanoDano I think you are missing the point here. Whilst the fork was made when @visualfc was on haitus to try and keep activity moving, when @visualfc returned, the idea of a fork was dropped. The idea now is to have an organization behind LiteIDE not to have a fork or a personal project. This is not about power or personalities, it is about marketing and continuity. With an organization led by @visualfc, organizations using Go will be happier committing to use of LiteIDE because they know the project can continue independent of any one person's presence or absence. Having LiteIDE as a personal project of one person is a barrier to corporate use.

robvdl:
A bit of a question here...
The problem with this commit is that other Go web frameworks might have their own conventions for template file extensions, for example Beego seem to use .tpl, and you could just keep adding to this list in liteeditor.xml, in order to try to support the major Go web frameworks.
Rather than doing that, it would be nice to have it so that when you are under options in Lite IDE, and editing file types, make it so that you can double click on the file extensions and edit them in the form they are currently in (separated by semi colons), then hit enter to save.  This way the user can add their own extensions.
The main problem I can see with implementing this is that this list of extensions currently comes from the liteeditor.xml file which is in the program folder, and settings are stored in the ini file in the users home folder.  you don't really want to write changes to the xml file in the program folder.

helambuapps:
I had a problem running the pre compiled binary because of Qt version incompatibility. I recompiled the LiteIDE from the source using the latest Qt 5.3.0.
So, in the beginning I thought something was not linked up properly with the Qt libraries or something went wrong while I compiled,
However, I have just figured out, it is in fact a very simple fix. The problem is, the folder containing .go files can't have the name "go".
I simply renamed the folder "~/Desktop/go" to "~/Desktop/somethingelse" and it worked like a charm.
LiteIDE creates a binary executable with the name equals to the name of the parent folder. In my case "~/Desktop/go/go". I reckon, in this particular situation LiteIDE  gets confused and thinks the file "~/Desktop/go/go" is important because I believe it conflicts with the file/command "~/go/bin/go" (or wherever you install go) and so can't override.
:-)

. I have been using LiteIDE in Linux for years without any trouble. In MacOS it wasn't working for me. So I am going to write what I did as a reminder to myself in the future and also, in case someone else struggles, might find this useful.


From LiteIDE, select the right environment which should be local and 32/64 and OS selection. In my case is MAC OS 64, so I should pick darwin64-local


Open a terminal and run this command


go env
Pay special attention to GOROOT value, since it may be different depending on which installation you executed (golang installer, brew, zip, etc). In my case I used brew, so the path value is
GOROOT="/usr/local/Cellar/go/1.8/libexec"
Lastly, copy/paste that value in LiteIDE environment. Save the file and you should be good to go..

. I found a way to do it. You can define your commands in share/liteide/litebuild/gosrc.xml and they will appear in the toolbar and respond to the shortcuts. For example:
<action id="MyCmd" img="blue/run.png" key="Ctrl+Alt+x" cmd="ls" args="$(TARGETARGS)" output="true" codec="utf-8" readline="true"/>
will print the output of "ls".

msheakoski:
It's an issue with the goimports command line tool that happens when the package name doesn't match the part after the last / in the import. It thinks the import is unused. You can fix it by doing:
go
import (
    "fmt"
    stathat "github.com/stathat/go"
)
.
jbuberel:
[Note: I am the product manager for the Go language, tools and ecosystem at Google.]
Just a quick follow-up here. I've been discussing this issue with bradfitz (the goimports author) on this bug thread: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/10363
We've agreed to close that issue as "works as intended" because the stathat/go package violates two conventions used by tools like gofmt and goimports:
- Third-party packages should avoid using /go/ in any part of their import path, because that is used to identify source that is part of the Go standard library. Ex: "github.com/stathat/go"
- Package names should match the directory name in which they're located. In this case, the tool will make the assumption that the sources found in that directory should have a package name of "go", which they do not.
My recommendation would be to resolve this issue as "will not fix", with the recommended workaround of providing a package name aliast, as indicated by @msheakoski above.
.

gosharplite:
Building liteide from source default system.env to "native compiler linux 386", which might not be your system.
@visualfc has provided correct solution - "please check selected env and env setup".
. Liteide menu -> view -> edit current environment
Check if there is difference between the open file and your go env.
Mine are shown below.
$ go env
GOARCH="amd64"
GOBIN=""
GOEXE=""
GOHOSTARCH="amd64"
GOHOSTOS="linux"
GOOS="linux"
GOPATH="/home/tony/go/gopath"
GORACE=""
GOROOT="/home/tony/go/go"
GOTOOLDIR="/home/tony/go/go/pkg/tool/linux_amd64"
GO15VENDOREXPERIMENT=""
CC="gcc"
GOGCCFLAGS="-fPIC -m64 -pthread -fmessage-length=0"
CXX="g++"
CGO_ENABLED="1"
system.env
```
native compiler linux 386
GOROOT=$HOME/go
GOBIN=
GOARCH=386
GOOS=linux
CGO_ENABLED=1
PATH=$GOROOT/bin:$PATH
LITEIDE_GDB=gdb
LITEIDE_MAKE=make
LITEIDE_TERM=/usr/bin/gnome-terminal
LITEIDE_TERMARGS=
LITEIDE_EXEC=/usr/bin/xterm
LITEIDE_EXECOPT=-e
LITEIDE_SHELL=gnome-terminal;lxterminal;kconsole;xfce4-terminal;xterm
```

. @CuriousCain, I just successfully configure QtCreator on Mac to debug LiteIDE (grrr... and seems to fix crash with autocomplete https://github.com/vovkasm/liteide/commit/9e0e1345c06e996bc548e63245df352bd7fd76b5)
So if anyone needs step-by-step guide to debug LiteIDE on Mac, there my steps:
1. run build/build_osx_clang.sh (fail to build, but now I have gocode and gotools in liteidex/bin directory)
2. Open liteidex/liteidex.pro in QtCreator (select Qt5.5, but I cherry picked fix from @missdeer  https://github.com/vovkasm/liteide/commit/6bfc93ce5aa957d175bcac211eaf847db9a7d35b )
3. Build (not Run!) the project.
4. Copy files to bundle ($WC = working copy)
   cp -R $WC/liteidex/bin/* $WC/liteidex/liteide/bin/LiteIDE.app/Contents/MacOS/
   cp -R $WC/liteidex/deploy/* $WC/liteidex/liteide/bin/LiteIDE.app/Contents/Resources/
   cp -R $WC/liteidex/os_deploy/macosx/* $WC/liteidex/liteide/bin/LiteIDE.app/Contents/Resources/
5. Go to Projects -> Run tab -> Run environment in QtCreator and set GOPATH (and probably add /usr/local/bin to PATH to find Go and other tools)
6. Now I can run and debug LiteIDE ;-)
. This was fixed in these forks:
1. By @missdeer : https://github.com/missdeer/liteide/commit/08e7592540fe9afbb3d1d56a88f7aa347b7dc613
2. By @embroker : https://github.com/embroker/liteide/commit/1eff2b9ba1da6a3227ff8e493ab17ea7df23b621
3. I'am also incorporate fix from 1. https://github.com/vovkasm/liteide/commit/6bfc93ce5aa957d175bcac211eaf847db9a7d35b

I have found out that on OS X, using "Ctrl" in the Keyboard Shortcut dialog actually means "Cmd" instead of the "kntrl" button. Changing all Alt+ combinations to Ctrl+ fixed my issue.

gdm85:
@russel I think we should migrate the issues and the PRs to get it running :)
. Guys, just stop altogether. Want to fork it? Fork it. Open source doesn't work like "may I ask permission to fork it?". @visualfc is not a company and has limited resources, he will commit what he can/wants to this project.
If you have so much energy (also to write "bump bump bump", as I notice) and keep asking reactions from a person that clearly can't/doesn't want/doesn't have time, you might as well realize that it's more productive (at least from the open source/community perspective) to just work on a fork already.
There is no fragmentation because nobody is working on same issues at the same time; you make a fork, life goes on. Over time the original author can compare them thanks to GitHub tools and eventually cherry-pick/merge stuff later on. There is even a nice UI here on GitHub to look at all the forks and check which one is the most active.
(No offence intended, I just felt like somebody had to point out an obvious remark in this endless and useless thread :)
. @russel I know you forked, and that was a good start. But a community doesn't wait endlessly, and nobody can impersonate a community (not you and not @visualfc, a community is basically the bunch of people using/following your project and changes relatively quickly). My main point is that the question as per summary of the issue, doesn't make sense. You don't ask permission to make a fork, and IMO you already have a different idea about this, as you precisely described.
. @russel I am not missing it, I am arguing its usefulness for the purpose you want to achieve in the end. Simply that. But I am opting out of this discussion to avoid any further flames.
. @russel sure :smiley: to sum it up, if I were @visualfc I'd "let it go" (I know it's difficult...) and if I had forked the @liteide organization as you did (and had the will to commit time/resources of course), I'd start working on the issues/PRs altogether, accepting contributions. There is no hurry of course but I think people that want to contribute should do that under the new fork which is supposedly more active and injected of new life, no "formal" agreements are needed to do this, no work is done twice (as per current situation) and it can be folded/unfolded later on without much hassle.
.

There is no need to place it back into the liteIDE bin folder as long as the GOBIN flag is set correctly

. Over the past 9 months I've built it many times on Raspbian Wheezy and Raspbian Jessie Lite on a Raspberry Pi 2 Model B. I dont remember, but I think I started with X27 or X28. It works even better and faster with QT5. I'm using it with PuTTY and VcXsrv from my Windows PC. Currently, when built with Qt5, there is an error message at startup, but despite of the message it works without any problems. 
```

$ ./liteide
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 147 (Unknown), sequence: 164, resource id: 0, major code: 140 (Unknown), minor code: 20
QXcbConnection: XCB error: 147 (Unknown), sequence: 416, resource id: 0, major code: 140 (Unknown), minor code: 20
```

Building from a µSD card can be a nightmare and slow. Therefore I'm booting into an attached USB drive to build from there. Building with Qt4 takes about an hour and 75 minutes for Qt5. It will certainly be much faster on a RPi 3. 
Simply make sure to update Raspbian Jessie and follow the instructions for Ubuntu, it works like a charm for me.
. I experienced the issue mentioned in my previous comment with any version of QT5 I tested on Linux (up to 5.3.2 32-bit ARM on Raspbian Jessie and 5.5.1 64-bit on Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS) over Windows X servers on Windows 10 using PuTTY and VcXsrv. 
Meanwhile I found the issue also reported at https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-48453 and after some testing I can assert that the problem appears in other applications as well and is not a specific bug in LiteIDE. 
The problem disappeared after I reinstalled PuTTY to the currently latest release 0.67 and VcXsrv to the currently actual release 1.18.3.0 downloaded from its original source at https://sourceforge.net/projects/vcxsrv/.
Before the update I completely uninstalled the previous versions PuTTY and VcXsrv including saved sessions. As such I also had a clean install and configuration.

Go 1.7 adds support for macOS 10.12 Sierra. Binaries built with versions of Go before 1.7 will not work correctly on Sierra.

I have same issue. I have delve installed, but when I select in liteIDE Debug->debugger/delve, it cannot find it, but from Console I can run it and yes, it is in PATH. Here what LiteIDE tells me:
DlvDebugger: dlv was not found on system PATH (hint: is Delve installed?)
Misconfiguration? May be there is a workaround so far?. If somebody looking for the solution: Eventually found a workaround after looking at the plugin code. It turned out that the plugin expects to have dlv in $GOPATH/bin, but not somewhere in $PATH. If you have dlv there be sure that 
sudo pkill taskgated
is run after signing the dlv. This makes dlv run in LiteIDE.
joeblew99:
@visualfc Can you add this to the main readme ?
For Linux and Windows, the install instructions fro DLV put DLV in the $GOPATH/bin, and so LiteIde finds it automatically.
For OSX, its different, and if using the recommended Brew install method you need to do something extra.
https://github.com/derekparker/delve/tree/master/Documentation/installation
On OSX; do the standard brew install as recommend by the DLV install page.
Test it works from your bash with 
dlv
Then just copy it from the where brew puts it, into your $GOPATH/bin
cp /usr/local/Cellar/delve/0.12.1/bin/dlv $GOPATH/bin
You might also have to run 
sudo pkill taskgated
. for OSX thats not correct. at least not for me.. Please let me know if you disagree.

thomasmcgee: OK, did a little digging. FYI this is because the binaries are not signed. Sierra is spitting this message out into logs "AMFI: allowing exception handler for 'gotools' (1135) because the process is unsigned." A lot. Like 500K a sec.. FYI I was able to determine that the application and all of the binaries included get quarantined by Sierra due to not being code signed. You can use xattr /Applications/liteidex30.2.macosx-qt5/LiteIDE.app/Contents/MacOS/gocode to see whether or not the binary is quarantined the xattr command will return "com.apple.quarantine" You can use the xattr command to remove the quarantine status and the app will run normally..

dogancelik:
Edit: nvm. As a temporary solution: there is a way to make it 100% Portable using yaP but it requires admin privileges due to required NTFS permissions to create symlinks. Although that can be altered too
Using a configuration like this:
```ini
; App\ and Data\ folders in Root
; App\ folder contains LiteIDE files
; Data\ folder contains "Roaming" and "Local" folders
; Root folder has LiteIDEPortable.exe & LiteIDEPortable.ini
[GENERAL]
application = App\bin\liteide.exe
[BEFORE]
symlink = %LocalAppData%\LiteIDE\ :: Data\Local\
symlink = %AppData%\LiteIDE\ :: Data\Roaming\
```
It's similar to how PortableApps programs work.. A similar problem is that I had to disable Ctrl+Alt+3 for Class View because AltGr (Ctrl+Alt) + 3 is # character on my keyboard. Just wanted to report, not a big issue for me..

cassandraMetro:
Hello,
I've found out some more info on that issue.
Issue is present in normal mode and fakevim mode.
Steps to reproduce:
- open new file in editor
- paste the following code into it:
package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
    fmt.Print("aaa")
}
func somefunc() {
    fmt.Print("bbb")
}
- now click on small triangle on the left of somefunc to collapse that function.
- now put the cursor somewhere in the middle of aaa
- insert " character
- the somefunc() gets uncollapsed now.

the same happens if you put the cursor right behind Print( and insert { or (

If you are working on a large file with 20 collapsed functions and all of them are un-collapsed just because you edit one line. It takes you 2 minutes to collapse all functions again...
Hope it helps :-)
Axel.

The problem is that PHP code is only recognized for highlighting by GFM if it includes the <?php delimiter. Add this to the top of each PHP block and you should be good to go, e.g.:

class GO_Example_Model_Thing extends GO_Base_Db_ActiveRecord {

jdoklovic:
I upgraded to x33.2 and the same issue exists, however, I think I know the problem...
in gosrc.xml on master the GOFMT variable is set to golang's gofmt command, NOT gotools gofmt:
https://github.com/visualfc/liteide/blob/c0b698a036f0b05ebd7921dcc7d43ac797a785e9/liteidex/deploy/litebuild/gosrc.xml#L5
But that's not the only issue... later in the file, the GoFmt action in the utils menus is set as go fmt not even gofmt.
https://github.com/visualfc/liteide/blob/c0b698a036f0b05ebd7921dcc7d43ac797a785e9/liteidex/deploy/litebuild/gosrc.xml#L51
I think the internal command mapping and gosrc.xml are getting in each other's way.
Also, I noticed that keyboard mapping Ctrl+Alt+I is supposed to map to "GoImports" but that doesn't work either.
To fix, this is what I had to do:

set GOFMT in gosrc.xml to $(LITEIDE_TOOL_PATH)/gotools
set GoFmt action in gosrc.xml to cmd="$(GOFMT)" args="gofmt -fiximports -w $(EDITOR_FILE_NAME)"

With that in place, I could use the build menu to properly format and adjust imports, however, the key command Ctrl+Alt+I didn't work.
At this point, I removed the key mapping from GoImports and put it on Build|GoFmt.  This worked as expected until I restarted liteIDE and then it didn't work anymore.
To get it working between restarts, I had to add key = "Ctrl+Alt+i" to the GoFmt action in gosrc.xml
Hope this helps!.

sp0cket:
预期是这样的
go build -o bin/debug server
cd bin
./debug. 但是这样操作之后的working dir不对，少了一步cd ./bin目录，输出的文件会读取程序当前目录下的配置并输出log目录到程序的当前目录。所以run操作应该是两部分切换目录之后运行. 抱歉  还是有点问题
go build 执行的命令是go build -o $(BUILD_DIR_PATH)/bin
在这个例子中$(BUILD_DIR_PATH)=server/
所以-o 输出目录是在server下面的  而server下面应该只出现源码  bin目录应当在根目录下而不是和源码在一个文件夹下面  我之前提供的例子go build -o bin/debug server是相对在project目录下执行的. 在GoLand中是分为三个目录  一个是Working directory用作run执行目录Output directory是作为-o参数输出目录，Directory作为build目录. 可以了  谢谢👍.
